A child of globalisation, Chris's music is international, and as boundary-less as it is barrier-less.

Music that is magic, that is numinous - a numinous ground.

If I could write a music that is simply sacred, secret, and beautiful, I’d be completely content.

I keep coming back to magic. I think I respond to anything that creates magic, and magic isn’t genre-specific.

(-Chris)

Art should be humbling. It should, rightly, remind us of how little we know.

My music is an existential bellow.

(-Chris)

This is a tractate on my music, but not tractate in the usual usage. In his 'A Tractate on Japanese Aesthetics', Donald Richie notes 'Among other ideas, Eastern aesthetics suggests that ordered structure contrives, that logical exposition falsifies, and that linear, consecutive argument eventually limits.' He He then presents his tractate in the as being in the spirit of the Zuihitsu - a word translated from the Japanese as ‘essay’ but nonetheless completely different from the western meaning of the word ‘essay’, with differing shades of meaning and histories. In particular, Richie mentions the Japanese use of ‘juxtaposition, for assembling, for bricolage… Many Japanese writers prize a quality of indecision in the structure of their work. And something too logical, too symmetrical is successfully avoided when writers ignore suppositions of the questions asked of them. It is then not the assumptions of the writer’s controlling mind that are followed by, as the Japanese phrase it, the brush itself’ before evoking Zuihitsu again - ‘following the brush, allowing it to lead. The structure is the multiplicity of strokes that make up the aesthetic quality, one which they imply and which we infer.’ (-Chris)

They can think about music and enthuse about it, and that’s all that’s necessary… One of the reasons why cultivated music is one of the glories of mankind… is that we are dealing in amorphous, highly abstract material without any specific thought content." Elsewhere, Copland says "The arts in general, I think, help to give significance to life. That’s one of their very basic and important functions." So what do I want my music to be? ‘An enchanting abstract experience, free from specific significance but not free from significance - an amorphous, highly abstract material without any specific thought content, giving significance to life…' (-Chris)

Maria Popova, speaking about Petrarch, sums up my own feelings about composer: "In a letter to his friend, abbot Peter of St. Benigno in Italy, poet and scholar Francesco Petrarca celebrates the relentless rewards of writing: Strangely enough I long to write, but do not know what or to whom. This inexorable passion has such a hold upon me that pen, ink, and paper, and work prolonged far into the night, are more to my liking than repose and sleep. In short, I find myself always in a sad and languishing state when I am not writing, and, anomalous though it seems, I labour when I rest, and find my rest in labour. My mind is hard as rock, and you might well think that it really sprang from one of Deucalion’s stones. Let this tireless spirit pore eagerly over the parchment, until it has exhausted both fingers and eyes by the long strain, yet it feels neither heat nor cold, but would seem to be reclining upon the softest down. It is only fearful that it may be dragged away, and holds fast the mutinous members. Only when sheer necessity has compelled it to quit does it begin to flag. It takes a recess as a lazy ass takes his pack when he is ordered up a sharp hill, and comes back again to its task as a tired ass to his well-filled manger. My mind finds itself refreshed by prolonged exercise, as the beast of burden by his food and rest. What then am I to do, since I cannot stop writing, or bear even the thought of rest? I write to you, not because what I have to say touches you nearly, but because there is no one so accessible just now who is at the same time so eager for news, especially about me, and so intelligently interested in strange and mysterious phenomena, and ready to investigate them." Music that requires Love and Attention.

I don’t think I understood then (or even now) exactly how profound this simple idea is, but I really think it accounts for so much that is meaningful to me - the interaction of circles and lines, the beauty of the finite colliding with the infinite, the periodic with the directed - that’s everything for me. Everything was there back then in this simple literary metaphor that I liked but couldn't fully grasp and probably never will.

(-Chris)

Music that exalts, and so expands, our little lives in the universe.

(-Chris)

My music details my restless and ceaseless curiosity about, and search for, beauty and meaning in the world.

(-Chris)

Dacher Keltner's book on the scientific study of 'Awe' describes so many experiences and connections that are foundational to my sense of my music, and composition more generally. He notes we 'create music, visual art, religion…to share in experiences of awe', that 'you can sense it [awe] in your body and feel its form in nearly every kind of music…', and notes awe's ability to quiet 'the nagging, self-critical, overbearing, status-conscious voice of our self, or ego... empowering us to collaborate, to open our minds to wonders, and to see the deep patterns of life.'

In fact, 'Awe' is so connected to music that it is explicitly listed as one of the 8 sources of wonder that lead to awe, determined by a huge cross-cultural study: 'moral beauty, collective effervescence, nature, music, visual design, spirituality and religion, life and death, and epiphany'. This not only directly connects Awe to music, but - for me - makes obvious how all 8 of these things related to one another, how our sense of the spiritual, and nature, connect to music by all participating in the idea of awe.

Going further, 'Awe is the feeling of being in the presence of something vast that transcending your current understanding of the world...Something larger than the self.' Jane Goodall believe that chimpanzees have a sense of the spiritual, based in the idea of awe, which she described as 'being amazed at things outside yourself', and Keltner emphasises that 'Awe occurs in a realm separate from the mundane world of materialism... a realm beyond the profane that many call the sacred.'

Speaking to musician Yumi Kendall, Keltner notes that 'For Yumi, music is a symbolic medium of awe. It is where we express and understand together what is vast and mysterious…'

In concluding his book, Keltner observes 'The epiphany of awe is that its experience connects our individual selves with the vast forces of life. In awe we understand we are part of many things that are much larger than the self.' This is what music is about for me, and so what my music is about.
